title.text: Statistical User Simulation for Spoken Dialogue Systems: What for, Which Data, Which Future? *

abstractContent.text: There has been a lot of interest for user simulation in the field of spoken dialogue systems during the last decades.
User simulation was first proposed to assess the performance of SDS before a public release.
Since the late 90's, user simulation is also used for dialogue management optimisation.
In this position paper , we focus on statistical methods for user simulation, their main advantages and drawbacks.
We initiate a reflection about the utility of such methods and give some insights of what their future should be.

introductionContent.text: User simulation for Spoken Dialogue Systems (SDS) aims at generating artificial interactions supposed to be representative of what would bean actual dialogue between a human user and a given dialogue system.
User simulation is thus different from user modeling which is often included into the systems to infer user goals from observable clues (user's utterances, intonations etc.).
In this paper we focus on statistical methods for user simulation, that is methods purely based on data and statistical models and not cognitive models.

Also, we only address user simulations working at the intention level, that is generating dialog acts and not speech or natural language ( The aim of user simulation was initially to assess the performance of a SDS before a public release ().
Given a performance metric and a simulation method, the natural idea of automatically optimizing SDS (using reinforcement learning RL) appeared in the literature in the late 90's ().
